image_analysis.description: A high-contrast, black and white scan of two pages from a book, showing pages 188 and 189. The image captures the text on both pages, the page numbers, headers, and the book's inner margin/binding. A document identifier is visible at the bottom right.
image_analysis.layout: Two-page spread from a book. The left page (188) is partially visible, while the right page (189) is fully visible. There are headers at the top of each page, body text in paragraphs, and page numbers at the bottom center of each page. A footer with a document number is at the very bottom of the image.

FILTHY RICH

“The parties anticipate that this agreement will not be made
part of any public record,” the document concludes. “If the
United States receives a Freedom of Information Act request or
any compulsory process commanding the disclosure of the agree-
ment, it will provide notice to Epstein before making that
disclosure.”

Remarkably, despite assurances they’d received from the
feds, none of the victims was consulted prior to the drafting of
this NPA.

If Epstein did not sign the agreement, he faced a fifty-seven-
count indictment and a decade or more in prison. But Epstein’s
team of lawyers had gotten him a deal so sweet it could have rot-
ted all the teeth in South Florida.

For all his protestations of innocence, there was every reason
in the world to agree to an NPA.

On September 24, 2007, Epstein did sign it.

Once again, none of the victims had been consulted or
notified.

189

HOUSE_OVERSIGHT_010530

“The parties anticipate that this agreement will not be made
part of any public record,” the document concludes. “If the
United States receives a Freedom of Information Act request or
any compulsory process commanding the disclosure of the agree-
ment, it will provide notice to Epstein before making that
disclosure.”

Remarkably, despite assurances they’d received from the
feds, none of the victims was consulted prior to the drafting of
this NPA.

If Epstein did not sign the agreement, he faced a fifty-seven-
count indictment and a decade or more in prison. But Epstein’s
team of lawyers had gotten him a deal so sweet it could have rot-
ted all the teeth in South Florida.

For all his protestations of innocence, there was every reason
in the world to agree to an NPA.

On September 24, 2007, Epstein did sign it.

Once again, none of the victims had been consulted or
notified.

notes: The image is a scan of pages 188 and 189 from the book 'Filthy Rich' by James Patterson. The left page is partially cut off. The text discusses the legal team and circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement (NPA).
